doc.repnme: Bettering banking : private flows and let sleeping stocks lie
doc.abstracts: This Note proposes that the immediate focus of financial reform in Central and Eastern Europe should be on privatizing the intermediation of savings flows, which affect resource allocation, not on privatizing banking stocks, which represent sunk costs. It is easier for both technical and political reasons and more important for economic reasons to redirect the flow of savings through private intermediaries, with better incentives to allocate credit efficiently, than to privatize the stock of accumulated savings in state-owned banks. The case for this approach to banking reform is based on the assessments that: 1) prudential supervision will be inadequate for several years despite attempts to improve it; 2) private intermediation would improve resource allocation only if the government does not insure deposits; and 3) the political pressures to protect deposits are likely to be much lower if the bulk of household deposits lie unthreatened in state-owned banks. The main risks of this approach are the possibility that politicians will backtrack on reforms and bank fraud. On the benefit side, besides the economic merits, the proposed approach has political advantages that may make it more likely to succeed.
